lessons.title: Character Motivation — What It Is
lessons.text:
Motivation is the why behind every choice. It’s the pressure in a character’s chest that turns wanting into doing.
You don’t have to like or approve of it; you just have to make it legible. When a reader can *see* what your
character wants and *feel* why it matters, every scene has a spine.
This lesson anchors the word “want” as a working tool. No jargon beyond foundation terms.

lessons.prompt:
Freewrite: describe a time you wanted something and took even a tiny action toward it.
Name the want in one plain sentence. Then rewrite the same moment without naming the want—
only show the action that gave it away.

criteria.show: At least one observable action or choice points to the same want.
criteria.hide: No armchair labels (no diagnoses or genre buzzwords).

strength_tiers.3: Said/Shown alignment reshapes the moment’s consequence.

lessons.title: Motivation & You — Borrow the Voltage
lessons.text:
You already understand motivation because you live with it. Map one of your own wants onto a character.
The point isn’t therapy; it’s precision. If you’ve wanted, you can write wanting with authority.
lessons.prompt:
List three real wants you’ve had (big or petty). For each, jot one action you took (or avoided).
Pick one pair and hand it to a character. Write five lines that make that want legible without naming it.

lessons.title: How to Spot Motivation: SAY
lessons.text:
SAY = the character names what they want. Use sparingly, earn it with pressure.
When spoken, a want plants a flag the story can measure against.
lessons.prompt:
Write a 6–10 line exchange where a character finally admits what they want.
Cut any lines that explain *why*; keep only the declaration and the pushback it triggers.

criteria.show: At least one observable action or choice points to the same want.
criteria.hide: No armchair labels (no diagnoses or genre buzzwords).

strength_tiers.3: Said/Shown alignment reshapes the moment’s consequence.

frames: Confession under time pressure: 'Before we go— I want ___.'

lessons.title: How to Spot Motivation: SHOW
lessons.text:
SHOW = the character’s choices reveal the want without naming it. Actions don’t lie.
Track repeated risks, sacrifices, and rule‑breaking as your tells.
lessons.prompt:
Rewrite the ‘SAY’ scene so no one names the want. Replace the admission with two choices
that make the same want obvious. End with a small consequence.

strength_tiers.3: Said/Shown alignment reshapes the moment’s consequence.

tells: Have them choose the harder route that gets them closer to ___.
Insert a tiny sacrifice (time, money, pride) that signals the want.

lessons.title: How to Spot Motivation: HIDE
lessons.text:
HIDE = the character masks or denies the want. Look for avoidance, overcompensation, and contradiction.
Use this to build tension that snaps later.
lessons.prompt:
Write a short beat where a character dodges a direct question about what they want.
Let body language and misdirection betray them. Add one tiny crack in the mask.

masks: Answer a question with a question.
Make a joke that almost says the truth.

lessons.title: Motivation Potency: LOW — The Quiet Seed
lessons.text:
LOW potency = the quiet seed. Want exists but rarely moves the world yet.
Your job is to make the faint signal legible without forcing it.
lessons.prompt:
Write a slice-of-life moment where a character’s want barely peeks through.
No speeches. One gesture, one choice, one consequence.

lessons.title: Motivation Potency: MEDIUM — The Growing Fire
lessons.text:
MEDIUM potency = the growing fire. The want drives choices with hesitation and cost.
This is where plot starts to feel inevitable *because* of character.
lessons.prompt:
Stage a pressure → decision → consequence chain.
Make the decision believable *because* of the want you set up earlier.

lessons.title: Motivation Potency: HIGH — The All‑Consuming Fire
lessons.text:
HIGH potency = the all‑consuming fire. Obsession overrides caution. Consequences reshape relationships,
identity, and the world of the story. Use with respect for cost.
lessons.prompt:
Write the moment of no return. One action that burns a bridge because the want is now non‑negotiable.
Do not explain—let the action prove it.

lessons.title: Tools — Actively Control Motivation Potency
lessons.text:
You can raise or lower motivation heat on demand. Turn the knobs: stakes, resistance, privacy, allies.
Mix internal pressure (fear, guilt, love) with external pressure (deadlines, threats, scarcity).
lessons.prompt:
Take any earlier scene. Produce two variants: one notch hotter, one notch cooler.
Change only stakes/resistance/privacy. Note how behavior shifts without speeches.

recipes: Hotter: add a ticking clock + public exposure.
Cooler: grant a small win + private space.
